intro.p: Consider the vector field \mathbf{F}(x,y,z)={{F1}}, and the surface S: the portion of the {{surface1}} {{surface1eqn}}={{k}} where {{cutv}}\leq {{cutoff}}, oriented outwards.

content.p: Parameterize \partial S, the boundary of S.

outtro.p: \partial S=C, where C is parameterized by \mathbf{r}={{R1}}.

content.p: Use Stokes theorem to find an integral which computes the flux of the curl of \mathbf{F} through S.

intro.p: Consider the vector field \mathbf{F}(x,y,z)={{F2}}, and the closed contour C: traversing points {{#V}} {{.}}, {{/V}} then back to the beginning, oriented in a counter-clockwise orientation

content.p: Describe the surface S bounded by C.
Use Stokes theorem to find an integral which computes the circulation of \mathbf{F} across C.

outtro.p: Note that the vector normal to S is {{normvec}}. Also note that the surface S can be parameterized by {{f}}. We see that the curl of \mathbf{F} is \nabla\times \mathbf{F}(x,y,z)={{curlF2}}, and when restricted to S may be parameterized as \nabla\times \mathbf{F}({{X1}}, {{X2}})={{curlF2flat}}.
